linear_regression_ols Package Documentation

Submodules

linear_regression_ols.aggregation module

class linear_regression_ols.aggregation.Aggregator(*models: RegressionModel)

Bases: RegressionModel

Class allowing simple aggregation of multiple regression models. Constructor takes a list of models (type :class:regression.RegressionModel) and averages their coefficients.

Raises:

ValueError – Models must be fitted to identical data

fit()

Fits model by aggregating coefficients.

linear_regression_ols.confints module

class linear_regression_ols.confints.ConfidenceInterval(lower_bound: float, upper_bound: float, coverage: float, estimate=None)

Bases: object

Class representing confidence intervals. Stores the estimate, lower and upper bounds, and coverage of the interval. Call print() on the object to view the intervals, or use the implemented getters and setters.

Parameters:

  • lower_bound (float) – Lower bound of interval

  • upper_bound (float) – Upper bound of interval

  • coverage (float) – Coverage of interval (between 0 and 1)

  • estimate (_type_, optional) – Estimated parameter, defaults to None

Raises:

ValueError – Bounds must be well-defined, with estimate within bounds

get_bounds() → list[float]
get_estimate() → float
get_lb() → float
get_ub() → float

linear_regression_ols.demo module

linear_regression_ols.regression module

class linear_regression_ols.regression.RegressionModel(X: ndarray, y: ndarray, add_intercept=True)

Bases: ABC

Abstract class representing a general regression model

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Design matrix (n x p)

  • y (np.ndarray) – Response vector (n x 1)

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Option to add intercept column to X if not already included, defaults to True

coefficients() → ndarray

Returns the vector of estimated coefficients for a linear model.

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

Vector of coefficients

Return type:

np.ndarray

compute_adj_r2() → float

Calculates adjusted R^2 coefficient

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

Adjusted R^2 coefficient

Return type:

float

compute_r2() → float

Calculates R^2 coefficient

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

R^2 coefficient

Return type:

float

information_criteria() → dict

Calculates the full-model AIC and BIC

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

Dictionary containing the AIC and BiC values

Return type:

dict

predict(X_new: ndarray, add_intercept=True) → ndarray

Generates prediction based on fitted model.

Parameters:

  • X_new (np.ndarray) – Matrix data points for which predictions are made, with shape (n_new, p)

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Option to add intercept column to X if not already included, defaults to True

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

Predicted values for the new data, shape (n_new,1)

Return type:

np.ndarray

summary()

Prints model summary.

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

class linear_regression_ols.regression.OLSModel(X, y, add_intercept=True)

Bases: RegressionModel

Implementation of Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression. It provides methods to fit the model, predict new values, compute diagnostics, and calculate key metrics such as residuals, leverage values, and confidence intervals.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Design matrix (n x p)

  • y (np.ndarray) – Response vector (n x 1)

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Option to add intercept column to X if not already included, defaults to True

annihilator_matrix() → ndarray
fit()

Fits OLS model to data (in place) by computing coefficients

get_covariance_matrix() → ndarray
hat_matrix() → ndarray
leverages() → ndarray
standardized_residuals() → ndarray

Computes standardized residuals for each observation.

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

Vector of standardized residuals, shape (n x 1)

Return type:

np.ndarray

summary()

Prints a summary of the OLS model, including the estimated coefficients and associated t-statistics, p-values, confidence intervals, and significance for each predictor.

class linear_regression_ols.regression.OLS_Inference(ols: OLSModel)

Bases: object

Class providing statistical inference methods for an OLS regression model, including confidence intervals for coefficients, t-tests, F-tests, and prediction intervals.

Parameters:

ols (OLSModel) – Instance of :class:OLSModel which has been fitted

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

confidence_intervals_beta(alpha=0.05) → list[ConfidenceInterval]

Computes the confidence intervals for each coefficient based on the t-distribution.

Parameters:

alpha (float, optional) – Significance level for confidence intervals, defaults to 0.05

Returns:

List of :class:ConfidenceInterval objects

Return type:

list[ConfidenceInterval]

confidence_intervals_bonferroni(alpha=0.05) → list[ConfidenceInterval]

Applies the Bonferroni correction to the significance level by dividing significance level by the number of coefficients in the model. Computes the corrected confidence intervals for each coefficient.

Parameters:

alpha (float, optional) – Significance level for confidence intervals, defaults to 0.05

Returns:

List of :class:ConfidenceInterval objects

Return type:

list[ConfidenceInterval]

confidence_intervals_mx(X_new: ndarray, add_intercept=True, alpha=0.05) → tuple[ndarray, list[ConfidenceInterval]]

Computes the confidence intervals for the regression function. The confidence intervals are computed considering only the variability in the regression function itself, not the residual error.

Parameters:

  • X_new (np.ndarray) – Matrix of data points for which new regression function is calculated

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Option to add intercept column to X if not already included, defaults to True

  • alpha (float, optional) – Significance level for prediction intervals, defaults to 0.05

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

Tuple with vector of predictions and list of associated intervals

Return type:

tuple[np.ndarray, list[ConfidenceInterval]]

f_test(R: ndarray, r: ndarray) → tuple[float, float]

Performs F-test on general null hypothesis R @ beta_hat = r. Used to test multiple linear restrictions on the coefficients.

Parameters:

  • R (np.ndarray) – Constraint matrix

  • r (np.ndarray) – Right-hand side of constraints

Returns:

Tuple with F-statistic and p-value

Return type:

tuple[float, float]

f_test_intercept_only() → tuple[float, float]

Performs an F-test for the null hypothesis that all coefficients except the intercept are zero.

Returns:

Tuple with F-statistic and p-value

Return type:

tuple[float, float]

prediction_intervals(X_new: ndarray, add_intercept=True, alpha=0.05) → tuple[ndarray, list[ConfidenceInterval]]

Calculates prediction intervals for new observations

Parameters:

  • X_new (np.ndarray) – Matrix of data points for which predictions are made, with shape (n_new, p)

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Option to add intercept column to X if not already included, defaults to True

  • alpha (float, optional) – Significance level for prediction intervals, defaults to 0.05

Raises:

ValueError – Model not fitted

Returns:

Tuple with vector of predictions and list of associated intervals

Return type:

tuple[np.ndarray, list[ConfidenceInterval]]

t_statistics(hypothesized_values=None) → ndarray

Computes t-statistic for each coefficient.

Parameters:

hypothesized_values (np.ndarray, optional) – The hypothesized values for each coefficient, defaults to vector of zeros.

Returns:

Vector of t-statistics

Return type:

np.ndarray

t_test(hypothesized_values=None, alpha=0.05) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray]

Performs a t-test for each coefficient to test if it is significantly different from the hypothesized value. Returns the t-statistics, p-values, and significance results.

Parameters:

  • hypothesized_values (np.ndarray, optional) – The hypothesized values for each coefficient, defaults to vector of zeros.

  • alpha (float, optional) – Significance level for the tests, defaults to 0.05

Returns:

Tuple with vectors of t-statistics, p-values and significance tests

Return type:

tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray]

class linear_regression_ols.regression.RidgeModel(X: ndarray, y: ndarray, add_intercept=True)

Bases: RegressionModel

Implementation of Ridge estimator, requiring selection of regularization parameter.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Design matrix (n x p)

  • y (np.ndarray) – Response vector (n x 1)

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Option to add intercept column to X if not already included, defaults to True

fit(ridge_lambda: float)

Computes ridge estimator (in place)..

Parameters:

ridge_lambda (float) – Regularization parameter (must be greater)

Raises:

ValueError – Regularization parameter must be greater than 0

hat_matrix()
class linear_regression_ols.regression.WLSModel(X: ndarray, y: ndarray, add_intercept=True)

Bases: RegressionModel

Implementation of (feasible) WLS regression.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Design matrix (n x p)

  • y (np.ndarray) – Response vector (n x 1)

  • add_intercept (bool, optional) – Option to add intercept column to X if not already included, defaults to True

fit()

Fits WLS Model (in place) by estimating weights (known as feasible WLS).

linear_regression_ols.variable_selection module

class linear_regression_ols.variable_selection.VariableSelector(model_obj: RegressionModel)

Bases: object

backward_selection(criterion='AIC', K=10, threshold=0)

Perform backward variable selection using the specified criterion.

Parameters:

  • criterion – Criterion to optimize (‘AIC’ for Akaike Information Criterion, ‘BIC’ for Bayesian Information Criterion, or ‘CV’ for Cross Validation).

  • threshold – Minimum improvement required; used as stopping rule.

  • K – Number of folds for cross validation.

Returns:

Model fitted to the best covariate selection and list of selected covariate indices.

compute_cross_validation(covariates, K=10)
compute_hold_out(covariates, ho_indices)
compute_ic(covariates)
fit_model(covariates, observations=None)

Fits the model in self.model_class for a specified subset of the data. :param covariates: list of indices. :param observations: list of indices (only used for cross-validation). :return: Fitted model.

forward_selection(criterion='AIC', K=10, threshold=0)

Perform forward variable selection using the specified criterion.

Parameters:

  • criterion – Criterion to optimize (‘AIC’ for Akaike Information Criterion, ‘BIC’ for Bayesian Information Criterion, or ‘CV’ for Cross Validation).

  • threshold – Minimum improvement required; used as stopping rule.

  • K – Number of folds for cross validation.

Returns:

Model fitted to the best covariate selection and list of selected covariate indices.

partition(K, list)
